channel.title: Bloomberg Markets
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: Hong Kong, Saudi Bourses Seek Deeper Ties to Spur Trading
item.description: Hong Kong and Saudi Arabia are ramping up efforts to boost trading activity as inflows to their exchange-traded funds wane and cross-listings fail to materialize.
item.dc:creator: Filipe Pacheco

item.title: Bitcoin ETFs Pull In $9 Billion as Investors Ditch Gold Holdings
item.description: A divergence is emerging in US exchange-traded funds as investors move from gold to its so-called digital counterpart, Bitcoin.
item.dc:creator: Sidhartha Shukla

item.title: Possible Impact of US Crackdown on Chinese Student Visas
item.description: The US plans to "aggressively" revoke visas for Chinese students with connections to the CCP Party or studying in critical fields, according to a statement by Secretary of State Marco Rubio. There will also be enhanced scrutiny of all future visa applications from China and Hong Kong. Huini Gu, founder and CEO of the Zoomin Academy, shares her views on the possible impact of the policy. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Silicon Quantum Computing CEO on Quantum Industry
item.description: Michelle Simmons, Founder and CEO at Silicon Quantum Computing, discusses the landscape for quantum computing. She speaks with David Ingles from the sidelines of the “UBS Asian Investment Conference” in Hong Kong. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: UBS’ Lo on APAC Family Offices, Markets
item.description: Amy Lo, Chairman at UBS GWM Asia and Head and Chief Executive at UBS Hong Kong, discusses the outlook for family offices and latest market sentiment. She speaks with David Ingles from the sidelines of the “UBS Asian Investment Conference” in Hong Kong. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Aramco Boss Will Keep Borrowing Even as Oil Slump Cuts Cashflow
item.description: Saudi Aramco is targeting more borrowings to finance growth and better leverage its balance sheet, Chief Executive Officer Amin Nasser said, as the world’s biggest oil exporter raised $5 billion in bonds this week.
item.dc:creator: Joumanna Bercetche, Anthony Di Paola

media:content.media:description: Amin Nasser Photographer: F. Carter Smith/Bloomberg

item.title: UBS Securities’ Moriya on Japan Markets, Strategy
item.description: Nozomi Moriya, Japan Equity Strategist at UBS Securities, discusses her outlook for Japanese markets and investment strategy. She speaks with David Ingles from the sidelines of the “UBS Asian Investment Conference” in Hong Kong. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Sweden’s Snigel Plots IPO as European Defense Boom Fuels Growth
item.description: Swedish group Snigel AB is weighing a stock market listing the year after next as demand for its tactical military gear hits new heights on the back of Europe’s rearmament efforts.
item.dc:creator: Jonas Ekblom

media:content.media:description: Snigel AB specializes in backpacks and bulletproof vests for elite forces. Source: Snigel AB

item.title: Stock Futures Jump, Dollar Gains on Tariff Ruling: Markets Wrap
item.description: US assets got a boost Thursday after a vast majority of President Donald Trump’s global tariffs were deemed illegal and blocked by the US trade court. Upbeat earnings from Nvidia Corp. also lifted investor sentiment.
item.dc:creator: Anand Krishnamoorthy

item.title: Bloomberg: The Asia Trade 05/29/2025
item.description: "Bloomberg: The Asia Trade" brings you everything you need to know to get ahead as the trading day begins in Asia. Bloomberg TV is live from Sydney with Paul Allen and Haidi Stroud-Watts, getting insight and analysis from newsmakers and industry leaders on the biggest stories shaping global markets. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Tariff Uncertainty Will Go On And On: Peterson Institute
item.description: Peterson Institute Senior Fellow Olivier Blanchard speaks to Bloomberg TV's David Ingles on the uncertainty in the market as Donald Trump's global tariffs are deemed illegal by a US trade court. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Oil Climbs in Risk-On Mood as Trade Court Blocks Trump’s Tariffs
item.description: Oil advanced alongside equity markets after a US trade court blocked President Donald Trump’s global tariffs, deeming them illegal.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Chen

item.title: K-Pop Giant Hybe Opens Office in Beijing to Tap Chinese Market
item.description: Hybe Co., the company behind K-pop sensation BTS, has opened its first office in China in the wake of rising expectations that Beijing will soon lift a near-decade-long ban on Korean pop performances in the mainland.
item.dc:creator: Sohee Kim

media:content.media:description: A woman walks past the photograph of Jin, a member of K-pop boy band BTS, near the Hybe Co. headquarters in Seoul.

item.title: Indian Stocks to Catch up With Asian Peers in Second Half of 2025
item.description: Before the trading day starts we bring you a digest of the key news and events that are likely to move markets. Today we look at:
item.dc:creator: Alex Gabriel Simon

item.title: EQT Gets $162 Million Loan for Payout to Indira IVF Stakeholders
item.description: Swedish private equity firm EQT AB has obtained an around $162 million loan to finance a payout to shareholders of India’s fertility services provider Indira IVF, which it owns a majority stake in, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Kari Soo Lindberg, Saikat Das

item.title: China’s Steel Output Cuts Could Intensify Coking Coal’s Plunge
item.description: China’s declining steel demand is sweeping through related markets, with prices of the coking coal and coke used in blast furnaces plunging to their lowest since 2016.
item.dc:creator: Dan Murtaugh, Kathy Chen

item.title: Hong Kong Bankers On Edge Over $11 Billion New World Loan
item.description: Hong Kong bankers have become fixated on an $11 billion loan deal with unusually high stakes for the financial hub.
item.dc:creator: Apple Ka Ying Li, Denise Wee

media:content.media:description: Victoria Dockside is New World’s flagship commercial complex located at the core area of Tsim Sha Tsui waterfront.

item.title: US to Start Revoking Chinese Student Visas, Escalating Crackdown
item.description: The US plans to start “aggressively” revoking visas for Chinese students, Secretary of State Marco Rubio has said, escalating the Trump administration’s push for greater scrutiny of foreigners attending American universities. Bloomberg TV's Minmin Low reports. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: New Zealand's RBNZ Governor Hawkesby On Economic Outlook
item.description: Reserve Bank of New Zealand’s Governor Christian Hawkesby speaks on Bloomberg TV about New Zealand's economic outlook and the impact of global economic uncertainty. He speaks the same week as the central bank’s Monetary Policy Committee lowered the Official Cash Rate by 25 basis points to 3.25%, as expected by most economists. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Nvidia CEO Warns That Chinese AI Rivals Are Now ‘Formidable’
item.description: Nvidia Corp. Chief Executive Officer Jensen Huang said that Chinese AI rivals are filling the void left by the departure of US companies from that market, and their technology is becoming more powerful.
item.dc:creator: Ian King, Edward Ludlow

media:content.media:description: Jensen Huang Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

item.title: Gold Falls for Fourth Day as US Court Blocks Trump Tariffs
item.description: Gold extended declines for a fourth day, as markets absorbed news that the US trade court has blocked President Donald Trump’s global tariff agenda.
item.dc:creator: Sybilla Gross

item.title: Chevron Plans Nearly 800 Job Reductions in the Permian Basin
item.description: Chevron Corp. plans to lay off nearly 800 employees in the Permian Basin, its biggest oil-production operation globally.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Crowley

media:content.media:description: A Nabors Industries Ltd. roughneck uses a power washer to clean the drilling floor of a rig drilling for Chevron Corp. in the Permian Basin near Midland, Texas, U.S., on Thursday, March 1, 2018. Chevron, the world's third-largest publicly traded oil producer, is spending $3.3 billion this year in the Permian and an additional $1 billion in other shale basins. Its expansion will further bolster U.S. oil output, which already exceeds 10 million barrels a day, surpassing the record set in 1970.

item.title: Nvidia Delivers Solid Earnings Despite China Hit | Bloomberg Technology 5/28/2025
item.description: Bloomberg’s Ed Ludlow is joined by Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang to discuss the chipmaker's first-quarter earnings and the company’s $8 billion hit from China. Plus Ayako Yoshioka, from Wealth Enhancement Group says earnings show Nvidia understands the outlook for AI growth. And D.A. Davidson Managing Director Gil Luria also explains what he wants to hear from Nvidia next as it competes with Chinese rivals. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: FX Hedging Cost Drop Sparks Debate on Asian Bond Protection Bets
item.description: A decline in currency hedging costs across Asia is fueling a debate among bond investors on whether they should fortify their portfolios with cheap protection or let the opportunity slide.
item.dc:creator: Marcus Wong

item.title: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang on AI, Musk and Trump
item.description: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang discusses the chipmaker’s first-quarter earnings with Bloomberg’s Ed Ludlow. The pair talks about international expansion, US chip curbs on China and AI demand on a special edition of “Bloomberg Technology.”

item.title: Nvidia Tie-Up helps Vietnamese Tech Tycoon Bet Big On AI
item.description: Vietnamese tech tycoon Truong Gia Binh founded FPT nearly 40 years ago. From robots and software to telecoms and data centers, it’s investing in AI with partners like Nvidia. Binh is embedding AI education in the classroom and sees the next generation as the key to Vietnam’s development. Binh speaks to Bloomberg’s Haslinda Amin about his journey - and Vietnam’s - from the legacy of war to the fast pace of technological change in the latest episode of Latitude. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: UK Plans to Force Nation’s Pensions to Invest in Private Markets
item.description: The UK said it plans to require the country’s pension funds to invest in private markets and the domestic economy, a move widely opposed by the City of London’s investment managers.
item.dc:creator: Leonard Kehnscherper

item.title: Williams to Revive Disputed Gas Pipeline Projects in New York
item.description: Williams Cos. is preparing to revive plans for two scrapped pipelines that would deliver natural gas to New York.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy, Emma Sanchez

item.title: Stocks Climb Late as Nvidia Reignites AI Hopes | The Close 5/28/2025
item.description: Bloomberg Television brings you the latest news and analysis leading up to the final minutes and seconds before and after the closing bell on Wall Street. Today's guests are Kara Murphy, Kestra Investment, John Wobensmith, Genco Shipping & Trading, Olivia Tong, Raymond James, Yinan Na, Creatify & Jeffrey Katzenberg, Wndrco, Paul Christopher, Wells Fargo Investment Institute, John Belton, Gabelli Funds, Matt Bryson, Wedbush Securities, Andrew Ng, AI Fund, Sarah Kunst, Cleo Capital, Meredith Broussard, NYU Professor, Ed Ludlow, Bloomberg News. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: FountainVest Seeks $1.32 Billion in Arc’teryx Maker Share Sale
item.description: An Asian private equity firm is seeking to raise as much as $1.32 billion in a sale of about half its shares in Amer Sports Inc., as early investors in the maker of sporting goods including Arc’teryx clothing look to cash out.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Hughes

media:content.media:description: An Arc'teryx store in the Chelsea neighborhood of New York, US, on Thursday, Jan. 4, 2024. Amer Sports Inc., the company behind sporting goods brands Wilson, Salomon and Arc'teryx, has filed for a US initial public offering.
